name: Cuphea alatosperma
remarks: Distribution and Ecology. river and lake margins; 10–50 m.

name: Cuphea anamariae
remarks: Etymology. The species is named in honor of Ana Maria Giulietti-Harley (HUEFS), expert on the flora of the Serra do Espinhaço and friend and mentor of countless students of Brazilian botany. Distribution and Ecology. collected at the top of Serra do Cabral, a disjunct part of the extensive Serra do Espinhaço; in flooded areas of white sand; 700–1300 m.

name: Cuphea araguaiaensis
distribution: Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.588.1.1 Etymology: 'The epithet alludes to the occurrence of the species in the Upper Araguaia region, in the Araguaia river basin'.

name: Cuphea auriflora
distribution: Bahia (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.588.1.1 Etymology: 'A. Lourteig in 1971 identified that the collection “Irwin et al. 23426” belonged to a new species, naming it as “C. auriflora” in the labels of several herbaria. Since the name was never published, it was decided to keep the specific epithet as a tribute to Lourteig. The specific epithet refers to the yellow color of the flowers'.

name: Cuphea costata
distribution: Lagia Santa, Minas Gerais (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Cuphea dryadica
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.568.3.3 Etymology: 'The specific epithet is a reference to the Brazilian Phytogeographic Province “Dryades”, the name of the tree nymphs in Greek mythology used by Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius (1840–1869) to designate the region that roughly corresponds to the current circumscription of the Brazilian Atlantic Rainforest, where the new species is endemic'.

name: Cuphea exilis
remarks: Distribution and Ecology. Serra do Cachimbo in the southwestern corner of the state; open wet grassy savanna on sandstone; 425 m.

name: Cuphea filiformis
remarks: Distribution and Ecology. Goiás and the Distrito Federal; disjunctly distributed in northern Goiás and the Distrito Federal; cerrado, dry to locally moist or wet to inundated areas; 800–1230 m.

name: Cuphea harleyi
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.350.2.4 The specific epithet honors Dr. Raymond M. Harley.

name: Cuphea iguazuensis
distribution: Rio Iguacu, Mun. Sao Mateus do Sul, campo de inundacao do¹rio, Paraná (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Cuphea lucens
remarks: Distribution and Ecology. known only from the type collection.

name: Cuphea obtusifolia
distribution: Marshy ground, Piraguara, Paraná (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Cuphea petiolata
distribution: Rio Boccaiuva, Minas Gerais (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Cuphea praetermissa
distribution: Maranhão (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Tocantins (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.588.1.1 Etymology: 'From the Latin, “praetermissus” means neglected, that went unnoticed, in reference to the specimens belonging to C. praetermissa that were identified as C. tenuissima, due to the great morphological similarity'.

name: Cuphea rubrovirens
reference: Bol. Bot. Univ. São Paulo 11: 71 (-72), figs. 13-20. 1989 , as 'rubro-virens'

name: Cuphea rupestris
remarks: Distribution and Ecology. open rocky areas, cerrado, campo rupestre, campo limpo seco, and campo sujo, in sand and rocky sandstone soils; 1100–1350 m.

name: Cuphea tuberosiformis
reference: Beih. Bot. Centralbl., Abt. 2. 38(2): 295. 1921. ex Bacigalupi, Contrib. Gray Herb. 95: 16, pl. 4.  1931.

name: Cuphea venosa
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.568.3.3 Etymology: 'The specific epithet refers to the primary and secondary veins that are clearly visible and prominent on the abaxial surface of the leaves'.

name: Cuphea xanthopetala
distribution: BR 364, 190 km de Cuiaba em direcao a Rondono-polis, 20 km da estrada para Gruta de Sao Vicente, campo-cerrado transition, 650 m, Mato Grosso (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon aggregatifolius
distribution: Grao-Mogol, as margens do corrego na saida da cidade, na estrada para o Rio Ventania, Minas Gerais (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon alatus
distribution: Alto Paraiso de Goias, Parque Nacional da Chapada dos Veadeiros, na margem da cerca proximo a sede do IBDF, Goiás (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon argyrophyllus
distribution: Dist. Cantoles: Abaira, encosta da Serra do Atalho, em frente ao Mendonca, ca. 13°16'S, 41°49'W, Bahia (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon astictus
reference: Los Angeles County Mus. Contr. Sci. no. 72: 6, figs. 1963
publication: Los Angeles County Mus. Contr. Sci.

name: Diplusodon caesariatus
reference: Los Angeles County Mus. Contr. Sci. no. 72: 9, figs. 1963
publication: Los Angeles County Mus. Contr. Sci.

name: Diplusodon canastrensis
reference: Bol. Bot. Univ. São Paulo 22(1): 1 (-3; fig. 1). 2004
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon capitalensis
distribution: Brasília Distrito Federal (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Goiás (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Diplusodon ciliatiflorus
distribution: Colinas do Sul, na estra da Colinas do Sul-Usina Hidreletrica de Serra da Mesa, 23.6 km antes de chegar na entrada da Usina, 14°12'S, 48°4'W, Goiás (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon cryptanthus
reference: Bol. Bot. Univ. São Paulo 22(1): 3 (-5; fig. 2). 2004
distribution: Goiás (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Tocantins (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Diplusodon glocimarii
reference: Bol. Bot. Univ. São Paulo 22(1): 7 (-9; fig. 4). 2004
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon mattogrossensis
distribution: Ca. 270 km N de Xavantina, Mato Grosso (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon obtectus
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: Etymology: 'The specific epithet alludes to the main feature of this species, which are the large bracts that cover the flowers'.

name: Diplusodon plumbeus
distribution: Cristalina, a 5 km N de Cristalina, Goiás (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon pygmaeus
distribution: Alto Paraiso de Goias, estrada vicinal a esquerda, a 5 km S de Alto Paraiso de Goias no sentido Brasilia, GO-118, Serra da Baliza, no topo do morro, 14°11'S, 47°45'W, Goiás (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon rectinervis
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon rupestris
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon trigintus
distribution: Ponte Alta do Norte, de Porto Nacional para Ponte Alta do Norte, 20 km de Ponte Alta, Tocantins (Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon urceolatus
remarks: NY and P cited for type, without an indication of the herbarium housing the holotype.

name: Diplusodon vacillans
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon verruculosus
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon vividus
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Diplusodon xerophilus
remarks: Etymology: 'The specific epithet refers to the dry habitat where the specimens were collected'.

name: Gyrosphragma latipetala
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Lafoensia replicata
remarks: [Gandhi 22 Mar 1999] The type information is from A. Lourteig (Mem. Soc. Ci. Nat. La Salle 33: 134. 1973).
